title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: [SWANSTON COTTAGE, LOTHIANBURN, July, 1876.'} HERE I am, here, and very well too. I am glad you liked "Walking Tours"; I like it, too; I think it 's prose; and I own with contrition that I have not always written prose.

title: The hills of home,
author: Watt, Lauchlan McLean.
snippet: sore, in 1867, his parents took a lease of Swanston Cottage, at the foot of Kirk Yetton,  and he spent his time between Edinburgh  and Swanston, the influences and associations of green hill and grey rock, of misty peak and quiet and still places, took a large part in the moulding of his thought and of the form of its expression.

title: The hills of home,
author: Watt, Lauchlan McLean.
snippet: At the foot of the craggy face of Kirk Yetton shelters the little village of Swanston,  a clachan "in the woody sold of a green hill," with some thatched cottages near by. Beside the burn, encircled by sweet trees, is Swanston Cottage, for ever associated with the remembrance of the delicate youth whose creative genius has written his name amongst the Scottish immortals, and at the same time has given him a grip on the affections of the world. The view from Kirk Yetton was very precious to him; and somewhere in the hollow of those hills Allan Ramsay set the ideal scene of his Gentle Shepherd, though more than one site has contended for the honour of being the poet's Habbies Howe.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: [SWANSTON COTTAGE, LOTHIANBURN, July, ... I HAVE the strangest repugnance for writing; indeed, I have nearly got myself persuaded into the notion that letters don't arrive, in order to salve my conscience for never sending them off. I 'm reading a great deal of fifteenth century : Trial of Joan of Arc, Paston Letters, Basin, etc., also Boswell daily by way of a Bible; I mean to read Boswell now until the day I die.
